Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2020
Review Title: High quality phone at an affordable price!
Review Description: Best phone I've ever had! Nice feel to the hand. The back cover is plastic but solid. It has a gorgeous indigo blue finish but smears or prints easily. Who cares when everyone puts a cover on a phone anyway, right? Big screen size but narrow enough to hold with one hand. No worries about LCD screen. Very bright and easy to see. I was just out today in the sun and my screen very easy to see and read. Fingerprint reader is lightning fast. Fastest I've ever had. The cool thing is you can scan or use multiple finger prints so I use both my index finger prints a lot on it depending what hand I am using at the time. No face recognition but who cares! No idea why people have to have this. You're opening your phone up people, that's it. Takes a second. Geesh. Speakers are on both ends (dual speakers) so very nice and clear. Loud, too. I was out landscaping in my yard today, laid my phone down on a chair, and I easily heard my 80's music crisp and clear; did not need a Bluetooth speaker (even though that would make it much louder as we know). Headphone jack is an added feature. Camera is very nice! High quality pictures! Quality zoom focus and clear and colorful pictures (I have a few examples). A little cool feature is you can place 3 fingers on the face of your phone and screen shot. This is great since I screen shot a lot. When navigating through the phone, the processor is very fast and smooth experience. With all of these positives, then an extra bonus is the unique stylus tucked away perfectly. Writes very smooth and easily and is just plain fun! I'm a teacher, so very nice to have a note taking device when I quickly need it without frantically looking for a pen or pencil and paper. Just convenient to have in grocery store or when a quick idea comes to mind. Using screen protectors does NOT effect the stylus at all either. The battery life is Great out of my own Rating: Exceptional/Great/Good/Poor. Even though it's not exceptional, the phone charges fast, so no big deal in my opinion. I will never understand why people waste their money on a phone with a battery "on steroids" that lasts 2 or 3 days and pay an arm and a leg for it especially when you charge it up every night anyway. Also, amazing storage!Note: At first, I thought this phone didn't have the capability to change the volume on notifications or texts. Well, it does. The side buttons are of course for sound, vibration, or silent like most phones and are used for Media Sound for FB, YouTube videos, calls, etc. You have to go to SOUND in Settings and use the Ring Volume to control the notifications or texts sounds. There's also a Call Volume and an Alarm Volume in this same SOUND Setting. I hope this helps.For $299, I'm shocked this stylus and phone is so solid. Highly recommend this phone!The only negatives or cons is that it doesn't have wireless charging but not a deal breaker for me. Also, I wish it had a notification blinking light to notify me when I have a message but not a deal breaker once again.

Product Title: Moto G Stylus | 2020 | Unlocked | Made for US by Motorola | 4/128GB | 48MP Camera | Indigo
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2020
Review Title: Works and is fully supported on T-Mobile
Review Description: This phone was purchased after a lot of research because T-Mobile is shutting down some parts of their network to repurpose the frequencies for other uses.  This has resulted in my old phone not being able to function on the network starting early next year.It took me a lot of research to identify a suitable replacement.  In the past I have never paid attention to technical details of a phone such as the frequency bands it supports, etc.  But you have to if you plan to use this device on T-Mobile.  This device supports the important 4G bands that T-Mobile uses, 2, 4, 5, 12, 66 and 71.  The last one, 71, is particularly hard to find on many cheap unlocked handsets, especially from chinese brands like Xiaomi, OnePlus, Oppo, etc.  Major brands like Samsung support it, but sometimes only on handsets made for the US market, not the international versions (which are often cheaper and have additional features like dual-sim).I had to settle for this model even though it did not have some of the features I like in a phone at this price-point, such as dual-sim and NFC.  It is a shame how much manufacturers cripple a device just because they support one important feature that their competitors in the price range do not.  Because they can get away with it.So, here are the pros and cons of this device in simple terms:Pros:  Android 10, with very minimal bloatware, etc.  Mostly stock android with only a few moto-specific apps and featuresThe device feels solid and has an aluminum frameThe screen is very good, good size, good brightness, good pixel density.  High screen to body ratio, decent colorsThe touch screen is very responsiveVery good amount of system memory and RAM.  You will not run out of space for your apps, photos, music, etc. that easily and the 4GB of RAM means it is easier to multi-task without the device lagging or stutteringExpandable memory with a microSD cardThe fingerprint reader is quite accurate and responsiveCall quality is great, and the speakerphone is loud and clearThe camera takes great pictures, especially in good lighting conditionsThere are some neat features that require some experimenting with to take full advantage of such as your choice of Android 10 navigation or 3-button navigation, attentive display (to keep the screen on when you are looking at it), etc.GPS has alternatives like GLONASS and Galileo, so you are not restricted to the use of US GPS satellitesIf you prefer using a stylus on a regular basis or for fine work, this is one of the few devices with a stylus built-inMost importantly, I used the IMEI check on TMobile's website, and this phone is fully supported with all the latest features and capabilities such as VoLTE, etc.Cons:  It is not Android One, the pure stock version of AndroidThe device is a little chunky, with my old phone from 3 years back being significantly thinner and lighter (this phone is more than a third of an inch thick while many other phones are less than a quarter of an inch thick)The phone does not have gorilla glass in the front, and has only a plastic back - though it is shiny and attractive, if you are looking for more high-end construction, this is not the phone for youThe phone is not water or dust-proof.  It is splash-resistant, so you should be ok if the phone gets a few drops of water on it due to rain, etc., but don't immerse it in waterThe brains of the device is an older processor, and it is not as powerful or zippy as higher-end devices with newer, faster processors.  If you are an avid gamer with a penchant for high frame-rate games, this is probably not the ideal device for youThe screen is IPS LCD, not AMOLED.  So, don't expect black blacks and perfect color reproduction or extreme contrast.  And the refresh rate is only 60 Hz.  Many newer devices have moved on to 90 Hz and some high-end devices are setting the standard with 120 Hz and 144 Hz displaysThere is face unlock, but it is not offered as the default - mainly because it is 2D face recognition, so it is less secure and can be fooled by using an actual-size photo of you, for exampleThe hole-punch selfie camera can be a bit of a distraction since it draws your eyes towards itself when you are looking at something like a youtube video in full-screen mode.  I would have preferred a thin top bezel for the selfie camera, notification LED, etc.And speaking of notification LED, there is noneSame goes for NFC and dual-simThe camera is not great in low-light conditions - it is not bad, but depending on the conditions, it can over-expose bright areas and make the dark areas completely black, or it can make the picture grainy.  HDR photos can take a few seconds to process and you have to hold still while doing it, so pictures may become blurry because of shake if you use that featureAlso, the action camera, which is a wide-angle camera that enables you to take horizontal videos while holding the phone vertically, is a gimmick - it can only be used for video, not for wide-angle still shotsThe stylus is mostly also a gimmick - there are no special features specific to the stylus.  And the stylus itself is not an electronic device with its own smarts - you can use any stylus with the phone.  The only advantage of this stylus is that it fits in the phone's stylus slot so that you don't have to carry it around separatelyMotorola has a habit of not updating android versions on their devices frequently or on a timely fashion, so I don't expect this device to get past Android 11 - this is a future criticism and I would be happy to be proved wrong!Overall, I like the device so far.  It is in the correct price range (I don't want to spend more than $100/year on a cellphone, and I have never managed to hold onto a device for more than 3 years, so $300 is my upper limit for price).  It has full support for my carrier, which is a very important consideration.  The features on this phone are par for the course when it comes to devices in its price range, so even though I have listed many cons, it is mostly a wishlist that I wish can be accommodated on a sub-$300 phone rather than just the high-end devices.If you have specific questions about the device, please post as a comment and I will try to answer them.

Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2020
Review Title: The "back" button is maybe the most ridiculous thing on a smart phone
Review Description: I've had many Motorola phones, some being hits and some being misses. Mostly I don't care, I just make myself get used to it no matter what. This phone has a feature that is impossible to get used to, and is insane. I cannot believe it would make it into the finished product.Motorola changes the home, back, and open apps buttons with every new generation of phone. Once they find something that works, they change it anyway. I'm not sure why. They always change it. 100% of the time. With the Stylus you swipe the bottom bar for Home, or the open apps menu. No big deal. If you haven't had a phone like that, you get used to it. However, the back button... It is not really on the bottom bar anymore. You actually swipe the whole screen. So if you're on amazon, changing sizes on a pair of shoes... It goes back to the previous page instead of scrolling sizes. Any app that lets you swipe over to the next screen, such as Snapchat, Facebook, and almost all social media app... It goes back instead. It's not a finesse thing. It's not something you'll learn to get better at. It will do it at will, and at random. You'll swipe shorter, hoping it will help, and it won't. You'll swipe quicker, longer, slower... Nothing will help. It will just occasionally swipe you back and you will lose your spot. On occasion, this could be catastrophic and make you start over at something. This phone would be devastating to use for work. Hopefully they can update this absurd feature away.I also notice on this phone, it isn't precise with swiping. It's the first phone I've had in many generations that swipes poorly. You swipe up, and once in a while it scrolls down instead. Once in a while you swipe down, and it scrolls up instead. This will become very apparent with certain apps more than others. I am guessing it has to do with the added stylus. The screen has to be made to work with the included stylus. Either way, it gave up quality of use for some reason.The stylus will not work with other devices and other devices stylus' won't work with this. That isn't a big deal, but something you should know if you have large hands and cannot handle the skinny stylus included. The one you have with your other device almost certainly won't work. Keep that in mind.The phone is not actually bigger than the previous generation, it just has a larger screen. That is good if you upgraded but didn't want an oversized phone. It is heavier however. The screen size increase, does not increase the keyboard size at all. This was terrible for me, as I'm always looking for a slightly bigger phone. I have large hands and will have to end up one day buying a overpriced, bloatware filled Samsung to get my hands to fit the keyboard.I want to like the phone, and hopefully I'll learn to love it. At the time, it feels like a downgrade. Or at the very least, no improvement at all.
